Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Behavior of Sulfur During Magma Mixing and Implications for Magma Degassing and Ore Formation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed experimental study will elucidate the effect(s) of magma mixing on the mobility of sulfur and sulfur-affine elements. In particular, this study investigates the interaction of sulfur-rich magmas coming from the mantle that mix with more evolved magmas that are typically stored for extended times in magma chambers below the volcanic edifice and have relatively low sulfur concentrations. Understanding the behavior of sulfur during such mixing should significantly improve our ability to forecast volcanic behavior. In the atmosphere, volcanic-released sulfur (often during magma mixing) modulates climate and leads to acid rain in humid volcanic regions. Furthermore, sulfur mobility during magma mixing is thought to facilitate metal transport from silicate melt to magmatic aqueous fluids that are responsible for the evolution of societally important magmatic-hydrothermal ore deposits.

A quantitative understanding of how sulfur is mobilized and how it facilitates mass transport during magma mixing of andesite and dacite magma remains unexplored experimentally. As magmas hybridize during diffusive re-equilibration, sulfur-bearing phase stability is investigated as a function of time and oxidation state. Given differential diffusivities of different components in diffusion-couple experiments, diffusive gradients lead to transient local environments, in which sulfides and/or sulfates may in one spot be precipitated while in another area they may be dissolved. This drives complex mass transfer between the mafic and felsic magma. Reduced and oxidized conditions will allow the team to assess the role of sulfur oxidation state on these processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magma mixing is a fundamental process during magma transport from the mantle to the crust. Mixing is considered to control magma diversity, drive and trigger volcanic eruptions, and provide a mechanism to transport volatile elements (e.g. H, C, S) between different magma batches. The latter is likely an essential component of the formation of mineral deposits.

During the mixing process magmas of different composition come into contact with each other. The nature of the physico-chemcial processes that take place as the magmas equilibrate with each other have not been investigated in great detail.  We show for the first time that significant redox gradients may emerge when diffusion dominates during this process. These redox gradients persist potentially for days and even weeks in a stagnant natural system (i.e. where convection-related removal of emerging boundary layers is limited). The redox gradients are a result of the complex mass transfer that takes place across the interface where basically all ions (and electron holes/defects) in the system are involved in the equilibration. This process is not simply a diffusion process, but mineral dissolution and crystallization may further complicate the mass flux and also modulate the availability of various elements. E.g. as Mg-Fe silicates (e.g., orthopyroxene, clinopyroxene) are dissolved in a mafic end-member additional Fe and Mg is delivered to the melt phase at the interface, which leads to regions of high Fe and Mg right at the interface compared to the far field in the mafic and felsic melt.

We find that redox gradients of almost two orders of magnitude may arise near the interface and those gradients will influence significantly the transport of redox sensitive elements. Most notably, the delivery of S from a mafic end-member to a felsic end-member (a process considered essential when forming porphyry ore deposits) is controlled by the interface as the saturation of sulfides versus sulfates in both mafic and felsic melts is significantly different. Thus, as sulfur is control by the interface boundary so are likely other metals for which S is the transport agent.

The project connected two early career investigators with a mid-level career scientist.  At the University of Nevada, Reno and prior to the PI’s move at Columbia University a total of 2 graduate students were partially funded by this project and several other graduate and undergraduate students participated in some of the research activities. As part of this project PI Ruprecht organized a ten day, 18 person, five university, and five nationality encompassing workshop in the Chilean Andes to discuss magmatism in general, and magma mixing and ore formation in particular.
